oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Lecture - Sharon Lawrence - 2005-04-02
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Lecture by Jimi Hendrix biographer Sharon Lawrence from the Ford Theater at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on April 2, 2005. In support of the exhibit "Night Train to Nashville: Music City Rhythm and Blues".
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Sharon Lawrence;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Opening comments by Michael Gray. Includes questions from the audience. Subjects include: meeting Jimi Hendrix -- Reputation for shyness -- Beginnings of friendship -- Thoughts about the Night Train To Nashville exhibit at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum -- Influence of Hendrix's time in Nashville on him and his music -- His times on the Chitlin' circuit -- Comments about her biography -- Hendrix's childhood and his listening to country music as a child -- Hendrix's feeling about Ray Charles'album Modern Sounds in Country Western Music -- Reads section of the book about Mark Boyle and his story surrounding the assasination of Dr. Martin Luther King -- Questions about the ugliness of poverty, Hendrix's age at the time of his death and the popularity of his music today -- The artistic influence of Nashville on Hendrix's life and other major influences on Hendrix --

Time with the Band of Gypsys -- Black militant groups wanting his support -- The decline of the Jimi Hendrix Experience and the beginnings of the Band of Gypsys -- Hendrix's absence from playing in Nashville at the end of his career -- closing comments.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Lawrence, Sharon, 1948-;
